title: Counting Blessings, Not Burdens
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock sat on his porch, the weathered wood creaking a gentle counterpoint to the chirping of crickets in the tall grass. He wasn't known for being much of a talker, but he had a way of observing the world that made folks pause and consider things differently. A young woman, Sarah, hurried by, a frown etched on her face. Hemlock simply nodded, a silent invitation if she chose to take it.

Sarah hesitated, then slumped onto the step below him. "Just…a lot, Mr. Hemlock. Work, family, everything feels overwhelming."

He pointed a gnarled finger towards the sunset, painting the sky in hues of orange and purple. "See that? Free show every evening. Never charges a dime."

Sarah managed a weak smile. "It's beautiful, but…"

"Buts are heavy things, child. They weigh down the heart. Ever tried counting your blessings instead of your burdens?" He chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. "It's like tending a garden. Weeds grow whether you want 'em to or not. But the flowers? You gotta water 'em, give 'em sunshine, appreciate their color. Otherwise, they wither."

He continued, "This life…it ain't always easy. There will be challenges. But there's always something to be thankful for. The roof over your head, the food on your table, the love of your family, even the air in your lungs. These are all gifts, Sarah. Gifts we often take for granted until they're gone. What is that one gift you will take the time to acknowledge today?", He paused, giving her time to ponder. "Take a moment and whisper a word of gratitude. Sometimes we forget to water our flowers. Today, make sure that you do not forget to water your flowers."
image_description: A porch swing in the late evening with vines with small flowers growing up the poles, soft lighting
insights: Psalm 100:4 urges us to 'Enter his gates with thanksgiving and his courts with praise; give thanks to him and praise his name.' Thanksgiving isn't just a polite gesture; it's an act of worship that shifts our perspective and opens our hearts to God's presence. Colossians 3:15 reminds us to 'be thankful,' highlighting gratitude as a continuous practice, a fundamental attitude of the Christian life. Taking the time to reflect on what we have and show gratitude is an essential act of worship.
prayer: Gracious God, forgive me for the times I've focused on my burdens and neglected to acknowledge Your blessings. Open my eyes to the gifts You've bestowed upon me, both big and small. Help me to cultivate a spirit of gratitude, not just in times of ease, but also in the midst of challenges. May my heart overflow with thanksgiving, and may my life be a testament to Your goodness. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What are three things you're grateful for today? How can you cultivate a more grateful attitude in your daily life? Consider writing a thank-you note to someone who has blessed you, or simply taking a moment to appreciate the simple joys around you.
